tn.text: This is the next part of the story which is about Jesus and a Samaritan woman. These verses give background information for this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Now when Jesus knew that the Pharisees had heard that he was making ... John (although ... were), he left ... Galilee
tn.text: "Now Jesus was making ... John (although ... were), and the Pharisees had heard about the success he was having. He learned that the Pharisees had heard, so he left ... Galilee"
The word "now" is used here to mark a break in the main events. Here John starts to tell a new part of the narrative.
The reflexive pronoun "himself" adds emphasis that it was not Jesus who was baptizing, but his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
This is a polite request, not a command.
He did not ask his disciples to draw water for him because they had gone.

tn.ref: Then the Samaritan woman said to him
tn.text: The word "him" refers to Jesus.

tn.ref: How is it that you, being a Jew, are asking ... for something to drink?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to express the Samaritan woman's surprise that Jesus asked her for a drink. AT: "I cannot believe that you, being a Jew, are asking a Samaritan for a drink!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"do not associate with"
Jesus uses the metaphor "living water" to refer to the Holy Spirit who works in a person to transform and bring new life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You are not greater, are you, than our father Jacob ... cattle?
tn.text: This remark occurs in the form of a question to add emphasis. AT: "You are not greater than our father Jacob ... cattle!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"our ancestor Jacob"
"drank water that came from it"
"will need to drink water again"

tn.ref: the water that I will give him will become a fountain of water in him
tn.text: Here the word "fountain" is a metaphor for life-giving water. AT: "the water that I will give him will become like a spring of water in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "life" refers to the "spiritual life" that only God can give.
In this context, the Samaritan woman is addressing Jesus as "Sir," which is a term of respect or politeness.
"get water" or "pull water up from the well" using a container and rope

tn.ref: You are right in saying ... What you have said is true
tn.text: Jesus repeats this statement to emphasize that he knows the woman is telling the truth.
In this context the Samaritan woman is addressesing Jesus as "sir," which is a term of respect or politeness.

tn.ref: I see that you are a prophet
tn.text: "I can understand that you are a prophet"
"forefathers"
To believe someone is to acknowledge what the person has said is true.

tn.ref: You worship what you do not know. We worship what we know
tn.text: Jesus means that God revealed himself and his commands to the Jewish people, not to the Samaritans. Through the Scriptures the Jewish people know who God is better than the Samaritans.

tn.ref: you will worship the Father ... for salvation is from the Jews
tn.text: Eternal salvation from sin comes from God the Father, who is Yahweh, the God of the Jews.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: for salvation is from the Jews
tn.text: This does not mean the Jewish people will save others from their sins. It means God has chosen the Jews as his special people who will tell all other people about his salvation. AT: "for all people will know about God's salvation because of the Jews."
Jesus continues speaking to the Samaritan woman.

tn.ref: However, the hour is coming, and is now here, when true worshipers will
tn.text: "However, it is now the right time for true worshipers to"
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"worship him in the right way"

tn.ref: I know that the Messiah ... Christ
tn.text: Both of these words mean "God's promised king."

tn.ref: he will explain everything to us
tn.text: The words "explain everything" imply all that the people need to know. AT: "he will tell us everything we need to know" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: At that moment his disciples returned
tn.text: "Just as Jesus was saying this, his disciples returned from town"

tn.ref: Now they were wondering why he was speaking with a woman
tn.text: It was very unusual for a Jew to speak with a woman he did not know, especially if that woman was a Samaritan.

tn.ref: no one said, "What ... want?" or "Why ... her?"
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the disciples asked both questions to Jesus or 2) "no one asked the woman, 'What ... want?' or asked Jesus, 'Why ... her?'"

tn.ref: Come, see a man who told me everything that I have ever done
tn.text: This is an exaggeration. The Samaritan woman is so impressed with Jesus that she believes he must already know everything about her. AT: "Come see a man who knows so much about me, even though I have never met him before!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: This could not be the Christ, could it?
tn.text: The woman is not sure that Jesus is the Christ, so she asks a question that expects "no" for an answer, but she also asks a question instead of making a statement because she wants the people to decide for themselves.
"While the woman was going into town"
"the disciples were telling Jesus" or "the disciples were encouraging Jesus"

tn.ref: I have food to eat that you do not know about
tn.text: Here Jesus is not talking about literal "food," but is preparing his disciples for a spiritual lesson in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:04:34]].

tn.ref: No one has brought him anything to eat, have they?
tn.text: The disciples think Jesus is talking about literal "food." They begin asking each other this question, expecting a "no" response. AT: "Surely no one brought him any food while we were in town!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: My food is to do the will of him who sent me and to complete his work
tn.text: Here "food" is a metaphor that represents "obeying God's will." AT: "Just as food satisfies a hungry person, obeying God's will is what satisfies me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Is this not one of your popular sayings"

tn.ref: look up and see the fields, for they are already ripe for harvest
tn.text: The words "fields" and "ripe for harvest" are metaphors. The "fields" represent the non-Jewish people or Gentiles. The words "ripe for harvest" mean that the Gentiles are ready to receive the message of Jesus, just as fields are ready to be harvested. AT: "look up and see these non-Jewish people! They are ready to accept my message, just like crops in the fields are ready for people to harvest them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He who is harvesting receives wages and gathers fruit for everlasting life
tn.text: Jesus indicates that there is a reward for those "work in his fields" and share his message. The ones who receive his message will also receive the eternal life that God offers.
Jesus continues speaking to his disciples.

The words "sows" and "harvests" are metaphors. The one who "sows" shares the message of Jesus. The one who "harvests" helps the people to receive the message of Jesus. AT: "One person plants the seeds, and another person harvests the crops." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you have entered into their labor
tn.text: "you are now joining in their work" (UDB)
To "believe in" someone means to "trust in" that person. Here this also means that they believed he was the Son of God.

tn.ref: He told me everything that I have done
tn.text: This is an exaggeration. The woman was very impressed with Jesus and felt that he must have known everything about her. AT: "He told me many things about my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here "word" is a metonym that stands for the message that Jesus proclaimed. AT: "his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2;translate:figs_metonymy]])
The "world" is a metonym that refers to all the people who live in the world. AT: "all the people of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This is the next part of the story in which Jesus goes down to Galilee and heals a boy. Verse 44 gives us background information about something Jesus had said previously. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
from Judea

The reflexive pronoun "himself" is added to emphasize that Jesus had "declared" or said this.. You can translate this in your language in a way that will give emphasis to a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: a prophet has no honor in his own country
tn.text: "people do not show respect or honor to a prophet of their own country" or "a prophet is not respected by the people in his own community"
Here the festival is the Passover.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline and to move to a new part of the story. If you have a way of doing this in your language, you may consider using it.
someone who is in the service of the king

tn.ref: Unless you see signs and wonders, you will not believe
tn.text: "Unless ... not believe" is a double negative. In some languages it is more natural to translate this statement in a positive form. AT: "Only if you see a miracle will you believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Here "word" is a metonym that refers to the message that Jesus spoke. AT: "believed the message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This word is used to mark two events that are happening at the same time. As the official was going home, his servants were coming to meet him on the road.

tn.ref: So he himself and his whole household believed
tn.text: The reflexive pronoun "himself" is used here to emphasize the word "he." If you have a way of doing this in your language, you may consider using it.
Miracles can also be called "signs" because they are used as indicators or evidence that God is the all-powerful one who has complete authority over the universe.
